name: FMeshNaniteSettings
doc: Settings applied when building Nanite data.

PositionPrecision: Position Precision. Step size is 2^(-PositionPrecision) cm. MIN_int32 is auto.
NormalPrecision: Normal Precision in bits. -1 is auto.
TangentPrecision: Tangent Precision in bits. -1 is auto.
TargetMinimumResidencyInKB: How much of the resource should always be resident (In KB). Approximate due to paging. 0: Minimum size (single page). MAX_uint32: Entire mesh.
KeepPercentTriangles: Percentage of triangles to keep from source mesh. 1.0 = no reduction, 0.0 = no triangles.
TrimRelativeError: Reduce until at least this amount of error is reached relative to size of the mesh
FallbackTarget: Which heuristic to use when generating the fallback mesh.
FallbackPercentTriangles: Percentage of triangles to keep from source mesh for fallback. 1.0 = no reduction, 0.0 = no triangles.
FallbackRelativeError: Reduce until at least this amount of error is reached relative to size of the mesh
MaxEdgeLengthFactor:
Controls the maximum distance allowed between each vertex of the mesh on screen. Can be used to prevent oversimplification
of meshes that are intended to be deformed (e.g. animation using World Position Offset, Spline Mesh Component, etc.).
Should be left at default of 0 unless explicitly needed to fix oversimplification issues.
DisplacementUVChannel: UV channel used to sample displacement maps
bEnabled: If true, Nanite data will be generated.
bPreserveArea: Whether to try and maintain the same surface area at all distances. Useful for foliage that thins out otherwise.
bExplicitTangents: Whether to store explicit tangents instead of using the implicitly derived ones.
bLerpUVs:
Whether to interpolate UVs when simplifying.
Should be enabled whenever possible.
For real UV coordinates this allows calculating the lowest error optimal UVs for new vertices when simplifying,
assuming the UVs are used as normal texture coordinates and will interpolate across the face of the triangles.

Disable if data stored in UVs isn't valid to interpolate, for example if indexes are stored in UVs.
Lerping an index doesn't make sense and would break the shader trying to use it.
Note: If disabled, error from UVs is no longer accounted for when Nanite selects the LOD to render because
error due to arbitary vertex attributes that aren't interpolatable can't be generally reasoned about.
